name: MX-64
keyboard: Full stroke keyboard, function keys, cursor keys
graphics: Mode 2 : 256 x 192 with 16 colors (Hires mode), Mode 3 : 64 x 48 with 16 colors (Multi colour mode)32 sprites
sound: General Instruments AY-3-8910 Programmable Sound Generator, 3 channels, 8 octaves
ports: 2 joystick sockets, 1 cardridge slot,Tape-recorder plug (1200/2400 bauds),TV output, Centronics interface, Side bus (60 pins), Expansion bus
description:
This is a classic MSX 1 computer. It was also sold under the Daewoo brand. It's one of the few Korean MSX computers...

It has 64 KB RAM... Not much more to say !

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #20</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> USER MANUAL'S COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SORD BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SPANISH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> The renaissance machine is a "one-of-a-kind" system for the "one-of-a-kind" person who demands and will not settle for anything less than, the best.</font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"French people talking to french people"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>A pretty secretary, a clean office with nice colours, and a computer working without any printer, cables, disks... Does it really sound realistic to you ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £149 IN JUNE 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy is so good as running his budget that he has become rich and bought himself a TO-7/70 ! Or did he get rich since he bought its TO-7/70 ? Anyway he is now smoking cigars and reads stock market newspapers... great</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JULY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (STUPID !)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated august 1982<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 464 - 6128 PERIPHERALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From top left to bottom right:<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 6128<br> - Joystick with joystick adaptor<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 464<br> - Disc drive with interface and CP/M for CPC 464<br> - Speech synthesizer and stereo amplifier<br> - Additional disc drive<br> - Light pen with graphics software<br> - RS232 interface<br> - DMP 2000 dot printer</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover of a French Commodore-PC brochure.<br><br> 'Hats off to Commodore!'  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CREATIVITY BUILT-IN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a French advert from december 1985 for a special christmas pack : TO-7/70 + Microsoft Basic level 5 + tape recorder + Colorpaint + Basic initiation cube for "only" 3990 FF. <br><br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOGS (1993)</strong></font><br><blockquote>WP-3 model</blockquote>

item.description: National CF-2131|||16 KB RAM expansion|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> NATIONAL CF-2131</strong></font><br><strong>> 16 KB RAM expansion</strong><br><blockquote></blockquote>
Casio OR-216 - 16 KB RAM expansion|||Box|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CASIO OR-216 - 16 KB RAM EXPANSION</strong></font><br><strong>> Box</strong><br><blockquote></blockquote>

Philips RAM expansion||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS RAM EXPANSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>RAM expansion and LOGO language cartridges.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Daniele from Italy</p></blockquote>

MEGA RAM DISK 256|||from DDX (Brazil)|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEGA RAM DISK 256</strong></font><br><strong>> from DDX (Brazil)</strong><br><blockquote>This is the famous Megaram cartridge made in Brzail, used to play all Konami cracked Megarom games.6401999243</blockquote>

Panasonic  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>
Sony HBI-232|||RS232c cartridge|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SONY HBI-232</strong></font><br><strong>> RS232c cartridge</strong><br><blockquote>Used to connect serial printers.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br>  It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br>  Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>

emulator.name: BrMSX
emulator.description: A Bresilian MSX Emulator written in 100% assembler

emulator.name: RuMSX
emulator.description: A MSX Emulator for Win95 and Win NT + Direct X

emulator.name: fMSX official Homepage
emulator.description: fMSX is a portable MSX emulator ported on : Amiga OS, Mac OS, MS DOS, OS/2, Sony Playstation, Risc OS, Towns OS, Unix / X, Win95 / NT, X68K.

emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.
emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and  MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
